DataElement.preferredName: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Annotation Gene Location GeneLocation
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.:An explanatory or critical comment that has been added to a text._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).:A position, site, or point in space where something can be found._the area of the gene containing or adjacent to the SNP, if any.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Annotation Gene Location
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.:An explanatory or critical comment that has been added to a text._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).:A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.:An explanatory or critical comment that has been added to a text.

Concepts.definition: A variation of a single nucleotide at a specific location of the genome due to base substitution, present at an appreciable frequency between individuals of a single interbreeding population.
An explanatory or critical comment, or other in-context information (e.g., pattern, motif, link), that has been associated with data or other types of information.

Property.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).:A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

Concepts.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.
A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the area of the gene containing or adjacent to the SNP, if any._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Sequences on the 3' end of messenger RNAs that are not translated into protein. The 3'UTR is involved in many post-transcriptional regulatory pathways, including regulating translation efficiency, mRNA stability, and polyadenylation signals.

Concepts.definition: Sequences on the 3' end of messenger RNAs that are not translated into protein. The 3'UTR is involved in many post-transcriptional regulatory pathways, including regulating translation efficiency, mRNA stability, and polyadenylation signals.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Sequences on the 5' end of messenger RNAs that are not translated into protein.  5'UTR extends from the transcription start site to just before the ATG translation initiation codon.  This region contains the ribosome binding site and other transcription and translation regulating sequences.

Concepts.definition: Sequences on the 5' end of messenger RNAs that are not translated into protein.  5'UTR extends from the transcription start site to just before the ATG translation initiation codon.  This region contains the ribosome binding site and other transcription and translation regulating sequences.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The sequences on a gene or messenger RNA that are translated into protein.

Concepts.definition: The sequences on a gene or messenger RNA that are translated into protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

Concepts.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Nonfunctional DNA sequences that are very similar to the sequences of known genes.  Many seem to have arisen as functional gene duplications that subsequently underwent mutation and loss of function.  Others are structurally similar to mRNA and seem to have arisen by a reverse transcription event followed by integration into the genome.  Some pseudogenes are transcribed and may play a role in regulation of its homologous gene.

Concepts.definition: Nonfunctional DNA sequences that are very similar to the sequences of known genes.  Many seem to have arisen as functional gene duplications that subsequently underwent mutation and loss of function.  Others are structurally similar to mRNA and seem to have arisen by a reverse transcription event followed by integration into the genome.  Some pseudogenes are transcribed and may play a role in regulation of its homologous gene.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

Concepts.definition: Single-stranded long chain of nucleotides containing ribose. It is the end product of DNA transcription by the enzyme RNA polymerase. It is essential in protein synthesis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Representation term 'Type' added per request of loading team to suport SIW requirements on 7/28/2008
